com.pump.image.gif

Class GifReader

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pump.image.gif.GifReader
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AnimationReader, GifConstants

    public class GifReader
extends java.lang.Object
implements AnimationReader, GifConstants
    This is an efficient way to iterate through a GIF image. This efficiently pipes image data from an InputStream and converts it into 2 important pieces of information:
    • image: a BufferedImage representing a frame
    • duration: a long, representing the time (in milliseconds) a frame should be visible.

    This class does not "look ahead" any more than it has to to prepare this information, so it has no way of knowing how many frames there are without iterating through the entire InputStream.

    Also to minimize the memory this class allocates, this object will not keep any data in memory from previous frames: once you've called nextFrame() the previous data is discarded. This should make it possible to traverse through obscenely large GIF files (I've seen 2-second GIF files that are over 1 MB).

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      class  GifReader.GifFrame
      This embodies all the elements that make a frame of an animated GIF.

    • Method Detail

      • isGIF

        public static boolean isGIF(java.io.File file)
        Returns true if this file is a supported GIF file with at least 1 frame.

        This method is optimized to skim incoming data, so it should be a pretty light call as long as the .skip() method of the FileInputStream is efficient.

        Parameters:
        file - the file to check
        Returns:
        true if this package can parse out this GIF file into at least 1 frame.

      • getDuration

        public static int getDuration(java.io.File file)
        Returns the duration, in milliseconds, of the GIF file provided.

        This method is optimized to skim incoming data, so it should be a pretty light call as long as the .skip() method of the FileInputStream is efficient.

        This method is optimized to skim incoming data, so it should be a pretty light call.

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        true if this package can parse out this GIF file into more than 1 frame.

      • isGIF

        public static boolean isGIF(java.io.InputStream in)
        Returns true if this InputStream is a supported GIF with at least 1 frame. Note that this method assumes responsibility of in, and will close this InputStream after it has read what it needs to.

        This method is optimized to skim incoming data, so it should be a pretty light call as long as the .skip() method of the InputStream is efficient.

        Parameters:
        in - the InputStream to check
        Returns:
        true if this package can parse out this GIF into at least 1 frame.

      • isAnimatedGIF

        public static boolean isAnimatedGIF(java.io.InputStream in)

        This method is optimized to skim incoming data, so it should be a pretty light call as long as the .skip() method of the InputStream is efficient.

        in - the InputStream to check
        Returns:
        true if this package can parse out this GIF file into more than 1 frame.

      • getDuration

        public static int getDuration(java.io.InputStream in)
        Returns the number of milliseconds this GIF should last. Note that this method assumes responsibility of in, and will close this InputStream after it has read what it needs to.

        This method is optimized to skim incoming data, so it should be a pretty light call as long as the .skip() method of the InputStream is efficient.

        Parameters:
        in - the InputStream to read
        Returns:
        the number of milliseconds this GIF should play. This may return zero if this has no frame durations, or -1 if an error occurred (for example, if the input stream provided isn't for a GIF).

      • getFrameCount

        public static int getFrameCount(java.io.InputStream in)
        Returns the number of images this GIF contains. Note that this method assumes responsibility of in, and will close this InputStream after it has read what it needs to.

        This method is optimized to skim incoming data, so it should be a pretty light call as long as the .skip() method of the InputStream is efficient.

        Parameters:
        in - the InputStream to read
        Returns:
        the number of frames this GIF contains. This tries to return -1 if an error occurs.

      • getFrameCount

        public int getFrameCount()
        Description copied from interface: AnimationReader
        If this can be determined, this returns the number of frames this reader will read.

        Otherwise this returns -1. Note that since this pipes images through consecutively (without caching anything), this may return -1 more often than you'd like.

        Specified by:
        getFrameCount in interface AnimationReader
        Returns:
        the number of frames, or -1 if it is not yet known.

      • getDuration

        public double getDuration()
        Description copied from interface: AnimationReader
        This method will return -1 if the total duration of the animation is not yet known. Otherwise it returns the duration (in seconds) if this animation.
        Specified by:
        getDuration in interface AnimationReader
        Returns:
        the total duration of this animation, or -1 if it is not yet known.

      • getWidth

        public int getWidth()
        Specified by:
        getWidth in interface AnimationReader
        Returns:
        the width of this image/animation, in pixels.

        This information is immediately available once this object is constructed.

      • getHeight

        public int getHeight()
        Specified by:
        getHeight in interface AnimationReader
        Returns:
        the height of this image/animation, in pixels.

        This information is immediately available once this object is constructed.

      • getLoopCount

        public int getLoopCount()
        This returns the number of times this animation should loop. This method may return -1 until the animation is completely finished loading -- although it is VERY likely that this information will be ready as soon as the first frame is loaded.
        Specified by:
        getLoopCount in interface AnimationReader
        Returns:
        the number loops, or LOOP_FOREVER, or -1 if it is not yet known.

      • getNextFrame

        public java.awt.image.BufferedImage getNextFrame(boolean cloneImage)
                                          throws java.io.IOException
        This iterates through the GIF file to the next frame image, or null if no image data is available.
        Specified by:
        getNextFrame in interface AnimationReader
        Parameters:
        cloneImage - if this is true, this method will always return a new BufferedImage. If this is false, then this method may constantly return the same BufferedImage, updated for each frame.
        Returns:
        the next frame image, or null if there are no more frames.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if a problem occurs reading the frame data

      • getLocalColorTable

        public GifColorTable getLocalColorTable()
        If a local color table exists for the last frame returned by getNextFrame(), then this method returns that table. It is possible (and likely) that this method will often return null, indicating that a global color table is being used.

      • getComments

        public java.lang.String[] getComments()
        Returns:
        all comments in the GIF file, each as a separate element in an array.

        Note that it is not safe to call this until the GIF has been completely read, because comments could appear anywhere in the GIF file.

      • getFrameDuration

        public double getFrameDuration()
        Specified by:
        getFrameDuration in interface AnimationReader
        Returns:
        the duration of the last frame provided by getNextFrame() in milliseconds. This information is not required in a GIF so this method may (in rare occasions) return zero.
